thread.title: Moore: This situation, Giants game should look familiar to Cowboys coach Jason Garrett
thread.title_full: Moore: This situation, Giants game should look familiar to Cowboys coach Jason Garrett | Dallas Morning News

author: David Moore
title: Moore: This situation, Giants game should look familiar to Cowboys coach Jason Garrett
text:
As confidence wanes and aspirations for the season are in jeopardy, as the Cowboys prepare to play the New York football Giants at 3:25 Sunday afternoon in the Meadowlands, keep this in mind.
The situation isn't all that different from what the Cowboys faced with an interim coach nearly five years ago.
DÃ©jÃ vu isn't a sensation Jason Garrett acknowledges. No surprise. It doesn't fit with his live-in-the-moment message to his players.
But for a Cowboys team operating with three consecutive losses, a backup quarterback and a defense that has been victimized for 95 points over the last three games, the similarities are striking.
The date was Nov. 8, 2010, when owner Jerry Jones fired Wade Phillips and dumped a 1-7 team in Garrett's lap. He inherited a team with a 38-year-old backup quarterback who hadn't won an NFL game in nearly three years -- Tony Romo was out with a fractured collarbone that year as well -- a beat-up offensive line and a defense that had allowed 114 points in its previous 11 quarters.
Text messages went out to players soon after the change that it would be a good idea to arrive at the club's Valley Ranch facility by 6:30 a.m. for a 7 a.m. meeting. Anyone who thought Garrett wasn't serious about a new day got the hint when he closed the doors to the first full team meeting two minutes before it was scheduled to begin.
Players practiced in full pads that day for the first time since training camp. They were required to run from one drill to the next, not walk or jog. There were no card games during the team's afternoon break, no domino marathons as there had been all season, as Garrett tried to rekindle the team's competitive flame and focus its resolve.
His overarching message was boiled down to three words: It starts now. Garrett spoke of looking forward, not back. He spoke of discipline and accountability and stacking one good day on top of another.
The Cowboys then went on the road and beat the New York football Giants, as Garrett repeatedly referred to them that week, by a score of 33-20. Afterward, linebacker Bradie James presented the coach he called "the Princeton redhead'' with the game ball.
Garrett's culture has had time to take root since then. There's no need for dramatic changes entering this weekend's game with the Giants. He will continue to emphasize the same approach, the same message, that he delivered his first day on the job.
"Adversity is inevitable,'' Garrett likes to say. "You have adversity every play, play to play within a series, certainly from game to game. If you're not mentally strong enough and you don't have the right character and the right makeup to handle adversity, you're not going to be able to handle the situation and you'll have a negative impact on the rest of your team.
"It's as simple as that."
Another simple message comes into play as well.
Next man up. It applies this week as the team attempts to overcome the loss of Romo and the demotion of Brandon Weeden in favor of Matt Cassel. It applies as Dez Bryant attempts to return for the first time since fracturing his fifth metatarsal in the season opener against the Giants with no assurance that he will.
It applied back in November 2010 when rookie free agent Bryan McCann, who found himself in the game after injuries to starting cornerbacks Terrence Newman and Mike Jenkins, returned an interception 101 yards for a touchdown and Jon Kitna got the win at quarterback.
Garrett did something in his first game as head coach that Tom Landry, Jimmy Johnson and Bill Parcells all failed to do in their coaching debuts with the Cowboys.
He won.
Jones didn't want to make too much of that first victory. He called it a baby step to where the team needed to go.
A win over the Giants on Sunday afternoon would be a baby step -- a potentially significant one -- to getting this team to where it wants to go. The Cowboys enter the game as underdogs, and rightfully so. That doesn't mean they can't win a game they're supposed to lose to the Giants.
It's happened before.
Catch David Moore on The Ticket (KTCK-AM 1310 and 96.7 FM) with The Musers at 9:35 a.m. every Monday and Friday and The Hardline at 4:10 p.m. every Tuesday and Friday during the season.
